SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, distinguishing literal from nonliteral language.
Content: What does the word DRIFTED mean as it is used in paragraph 5?

A.Choice: swayed

B.Choice: tumbled

C.Choice: turned

D.Choice: floated

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: What do paragraphs 14 and 18 tell the reader about Nico?

A.Choice: He wants to be a great juggler.

B.Choice: He is very imaginative.

C.Choice: He is a quick learner.

D.Choice: He wants to make Sam feel bad.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, distinguishing literal from nonliteral language.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
In paragraph 16, what is the meaning of the phrase “you're a natural”?

A.Choice: to use things from outside

B.Choice: to practice something

C.Choice: to make a good choice

D.Choice: to have the talent to succeed

Content: Which sentence from the passage BEST supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “ ... Sam taught Nico how to throw two scarves in an X shape... ” (paragraph 9)

B.Choice: “But it didn't take Nico long at all.” (paragraph 13)

C.Choice: “He began to juggle—slowly at first, then faster.” (paragraph 14)

D.Choice: “ ... Nico hurried out of the house with his magician's hat.” (paragraph 20)

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Read the following sentences from paragraph 24.
:box:“So what? Juggling is silly.” Sam spun the basketball on his index finger, something Nico had never been able to do.
The author includes these sentences to show that Sam

A.Choice: hopes Nico will admire him even though he cannot juggle.

B.Choice: is not sure where to place his basketball while talking to Nico.

C.Choice: does not want Nico to fall behind with his basketball skills.

D.Choice: wants to prove to Nico that he also has a special talent.

Content: Which detail from the passage BEST supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “... Sam's scarves and beanbags and balls kept drifting and falling and bouncing to the floor...” (paragraph 19)

B.Choice: “'I'm a good juggler.'” (paragraph 23)

C.Choice: “After Nico ran inside, Sam dribbled a few times and took aim.” (paragraph 26)

D.Choice: “'Try to do that, little brother,' he muttered.” (paragraph 26)

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Why does Sam say that Nico needs to juggle vegetables?

A.Choice: Sam is worried Nico will drop the balloons.

B.Choice: Sam realizes Nico is a very talented juggler.

C.Choice: Sam thinks Nico should begin juggling at the library.

D.Choice: Sam knows Nico needs to improve.

Content: Which TWO sentences from the passage BEST support the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “'He could juggle anything,' Sam said, 'even eggplants and cauliflower.'” (paragraph 7)

B.Choice: “'Do you think it's too late to cancel?' Nico moaned.” (paragraph 34)

C.Choice: “'If you do it now, you probably won't do it onstage.'” (paragraph 38)

D.Choice: “'Before you know it, you'll be as good as the one we saw at the library.'” (paragraph 42)

E.Choice: “He waved to Sam from the stage.” (paragraph 45)

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: Which TWO statements explain what paragraphs 35 through 38 show about Sam?

A.Choice: They show how well Sam played during an important basketball game.

B.Choice: They show that Sam feels guilty about the way he has treated Nico.

C.Choice: They show the reasons Sam was unable to play in a basketball game.

D.Choice: They show how Sam uses his memory of a similar feeling to help Nico.

E.Choice: They show that Sam wishes he could perform in the talent show with Nico.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, distinguishing literal from nonliteral language.
Content: Which word means the same as GLUMLY as it is used in paragraph 41?

A.Choice: calmly

B.Choice: sadly

C.Choice: angrily

D.Choice: quietly

SubTopics: Recount stories, including fables, folktales, and myths from diverse cultures; determine the central message, lesson, or moral and explain how it is conveyed through key details in the text.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
What is the central message of the passage?

A.Choice: Members of a family should encourage each other to share their opinions.

B.Choice: Everyone should find a hobby they enjoy doing.

C.Choice: Family members should support the interests and talents of each other.

D.Choice: Children should work together to learn new skills.

Content: Which paragraph from the passage BEST supports the correct answer to Part A?

A.Choice: paragraph 12

B.Choice: paragraph 20

C.Choice: paragraph 32

D.Choice: paragraph 46

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 3 topic or subject area.
Content: What does the word TRIMMED mean as it is used in paragraph 2?

A.Choice: cut shorter

B.Choice: decorated

C.Choice: carefully arranged

D.Choice: removed

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: Read the last sentence from paragraph 2.
:box:Some you can hold in your hand, while others are so big they need a forklift to move.
What is the purpose of the sentence?

A.Choice: It helps the reader understand that bonsai can be many different sizes.

B.Choice: It helps the reader understand that bonsai can be displayed in different locations.

C.Choice: It helps the reader understand the differences between the types of trees used to create bonsai.

D.Choice: It helps the reader understand why it is important to grow bonsai in pots.

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: Paragraph 4 provides the MOST information about

A.Choice: the definition of bonsai.

B.Choice: the reason artists train bonsai.

C.Choice: the different shapes of bonsai.

D.Choice: the types of tools used to shape bonsai.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 3 topic or subject area.
Content: Which definition BEST matches how the word TRAIN is used in paragraph 5?

A.Choice: to drag behind

B.Choice: to practice or prepare

C.Choice: to teach another person

D.Choice: to form or guide

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Describe the logical connection between particular sentences and paragraphs in a text (e.g., comparison, cause/effect, first/second/third in a sequence).
Content: Which statement BEST describes how the sentences in paragraph 8 are related?

A.Choice: They show the difference between two ideas.

B.Choice: They show the order of importance.

C.Choice: They support a popular opinion.

D.Choice: They explain a cause and an effect.

SubTopics: Distinguish their own point of view from that of the author of a text.
Content: In paragraph 10, what is the MOST LIKELY reason the author states that “Anyone can grow bonsai”?

A.Choice: to encourage others to begin growing bonsai

B.Choice: to show that clubs for people who grow bonsai are very popular

C.Choice: to prove that bonsai artists need help growing and shaping trees

D.Choice: to explain that bonsai live and grow for many years

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: Based on the passage, what is one way artists make sure bonsai trees will hold their shape?

A.Choice: Artists choose trees that grow more easily in larger pots.

B.Choice: Artists leave wires wrapped around branches for a few months.

C.Choice: Artists remove the dead branches from the trees.

D.Choice: Artists leave the trees outdoors during the winter.

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Which sentence from “Tiny Trees” BEST states the main idea of the passage?

A.Choice: “Bonsai is a Japanese word that means 'potted tree.'” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “Inspired by nature, bonsai artists create beautiful living sculptures from trees or shrubs.” (paragraph 1)

C.Choice: “Bonsai are not special small species of trees.” (paragraph 2)

D.Choice: “The Chinese first trained trees in pots more than 1,300 years ago.” (paragraph 3)

Content: Which detail from the passage BEST supports the correct answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “But a bonsai is far more than a plant in a pot.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “They are regular full-sized trees...” (paragraph 2)

C.Choice: “They called their miniature trees penjing.” (paragraph 3)

D.Choice: “They would often create elaborate landscapes or animal shapes with trees.” (paragraph 3)

SubTopics: Know and apply grade-level phonics and word analysis skills in decoding words.
Content: Which word has the same sound as the emphasized letter in the word m[i]ddle?

A.Choice: listen

B.Choice: finest

C.Choice: pilot

D.Choice: excite

D.Choice: donkey

A.Choice: tumble

B.Choice: closet

C.Choice: enjoy

D.Choice: ruler

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: In paragraph 9 of “Hobby Friday,” why does Chris feel that something is wrong?

A.Choice: He feels unsure about speaking in front of the class.

B.Choice: He thinks his grandmother will be disappointed in him.

C.Choice: He feels ashamed for not wanting to share his real hobby.

D.Choice: He is worried the class will not like his baseball cards.

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
In “Hobby Friday,” what does Chris like BEST about his favorite hobby?

A.Choice: He can get ideas from his grandmother.

B.Choice: He can share his baseball cards with others.

C.Choice: He can learn more about fashion design.

D.Choice: He can show his creativity.

Content: Which paragraph from the passage BEST supports the correct answer to Part A?

A.Choice: paragraph 7

B.Choice: paragraph 12

C.Choice: paragraph 20

D.Choice: paragraph 21

SubTopics: Refer to parts of stories, dramas, and poems when writing or speaking about a text, using terms such as chapter, scene, and stanza; describe how each successive part builds on earlier sections.
Content: In “Hobby Friday,” what do paragraphs 9 through 16 show about Chris?

A.Choice: They show that he decides collecting baseball cards is his favorite hobby.

B.Choice: They show that he is changing his mind about sharing his favorite hobby with the class.

C.Choice: They show that he needs to work on his hobby with his grandmother.

D.Choice: They show that he feels confident about sharing his favorite hobby with his class.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, distinguishing literal from nonliteral language.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
In paragraph 18 of “Hobby Friday” when Chris tells himself “Don't let them see you sweat,” he means that he feels

A.Choice: hot and uncomfortable.

B.Choice: proud of himself.

C.Choice: embarrassed.

D.Choice: very nervous.

Content: Which sentence from the passage supports the correct answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “Suddenly, Chris knew what he had to do.” (paragraph 13)

B.Choice: “Everyone in the class turned to look at him.” (paragraph 15)

C.Choice: “His heart was pounding, and his legs felt shaky.” (paragraph 16)

D.Choice: “There were a few snickers, even though Mrs. Griswell was shaking her head.” (paragraph 20)

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Based on “Paint the Morning,” which sentence BEST describes Malia?

A.Choice: Malia gets upset because she forgets what she wants to paint.

B.Choice: Malia wants to be left alone so she can paint.

C.Choice: Malia is thankful for the ideas her family shares.

D.Choice: Malia is satisfied with her final painting.

Content: Which detail from the passage BEST supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “She closed her eyes to try to remember the morning ...” (paragraph 7)

B.Choice: “Malia leafed through the brochure and saw 'Art: Pottery—Pinch and Coil Pots.'” (paragraph 8)

C.Choice: “She worked quickly on the little sign and hung it outside her bedroom door.” (paragraph 9)

D.Choice: “Malia smiled and picked up her paintbrush.” (paragraph 11)

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning word and phrases based on grade 3 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: In paragraph 3 of “Paint the Morning,” what does the word PEERED mean?

A.Choice: grabbed quickly

B.Choice: looked closely

C.Choice: laughed loudly

D.Choice: smiled happily

SubTopics: Refer to parts of stories, dramas, and poems when writing or speaking about a text, using terms such as chapter, scene, and stanza; describe how each successive part builds on earlier sections.
Content: How is paragraph 10 in “Paint the Morning” important to the passage?

A.Choice: It shows that Malia finishes her painting.

B.Choice: It shows that Malia is bothered by the noise.

C.Choice: It shows that Malia's idea is successful.

D.Choice: It shows that Malia's family walks quietly.

Topics: Reading Literature - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Compare and contrast the themes, settings, and plots of stories written by the same author about the same or similar characters (e.g., in books from a series).
Content: What are TWO ways that Chris from “Hobby Friday” and Malia from “Paint the Morning” are alike?

A.Choice: Both characters think of a way to solve a problem.

B.Choice: Both characters show their finished project to others.

C.Choice: Both characters like doing more than one activity.

D.Choice: Both characters ask for help from family members.

E.Choice: Both characters are satisfied with a choice they make.

SubTopics: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, descriptive details, and clear event sequences.
Content: The characters Chris from “Hobby Friday” and Malia from “Paint the Morning” both feel that other people do not understand them. Think about what would happen if Chris and Malia met each other. Also think about what things the characters would talk about and what things they would do together.
Write a story about what happens when Chris from “Hobby Friday” and Malia from “Paint the Morning” meet.
Use details and examples from BOTH passages in your story.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Describe the logical connection between particular sentences and paragraphs in a text (e.g., comparison, cause/effect, first/second/third in a sequence).
Content: Read the TWO sentences from paragraph 2 of the passage “Why Do Adults Think Video Games Are Bad?”

:box:Children like video games because they are fun and because they can be challenging. You have to solve problems, work out the best moves for your character, and decide how to use your equipment and supplies in the best possible way.
Which statement BEST explains how the sentences are connected?

A.Choice: They explain events in the order that they happen.

B.Choice: They make a statement that is supported with details.

C.Choice: They explain the difference between two ideas.

D.Choice: They ask a question and then give an answer.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning word and phrases based on grade 3 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: In paragraph 8 of the passage “Why Do Adults Think Video Games Are Bad?,” what does the word COOPERATE mean?

A.Choice: to create something new

B.Choice: to do something together

C.Choice: to ask for something

D.Choice: to fix something

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: Which TWO sentences from paragraphs 8 through 10 BEST show that playing video games can be helpful to children?

A.Choice: “One good thing is the video games that children play today often encourage them to work in teams, cooperate, and to help each other.” (paragraph 8)

B.Choice: “This is because games today are often designed for multiple players, not like old-fashioned video games that were mostly designed for one player.” (paragraph 8)

C.Choice: “However, children who are obsessed with video games and play them for a long time can get really competitive and can often try to win at all costs.” (paragraph 9)

D.Choice: “Experts aren't sure yet, but they have real concerns that this might lead to kids acting like this in real life too.” (paragraph 9)

E.Choice: “One thing you also might like to know is that kids who regularly play video games often get higher grades in math, science, and reading tests.” (paragraph 10)

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: Which statement BEST shows why playing video games too much can be harmful, according to the passage?

A.Choice: It can change friendships.

B.Choice: It makes children shy around others.

C.Choice: It is disappointing to lose.

D.Choice: It can cause children to make mistakes.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning word and phrases based on grade 3 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Which definition of the word CHALLENGE matches the way the word is used in paragraph 7 of “Are Video Games Bad for Me?”

A.Choice: to argue against something unfair

B.Choice: to refuse to do something bravely

C.Choice: to ask a person to do something

D.Choice: to push someone with a task that is too hard

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
What is a main idea of the passage?

A.Choice: Video games are a popular activity for children.

B.Choice: Playing video games with your family is fun, and it teaches teamwork.

C.Choice: It is important to spend time on other activities, not just on video games.

D.Choice: Video-game ratings help parents choose games for their children.

Content: Which sentence from the passage BEST supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “Lots of kids love video games.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “It's hard to get enough active play and exercise if you're always inside playing video games.” (paragraph 3)

C.Choice: “A good game will be the right one for how old you are.” (paragraph 6)

D.Choice: “Games are rated like movies, and your mom or dad can help figure out which ones you should use.” (paragraph 6)

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Compare and contrast the most important points and key details presented in two texts on the same topic.
Content: Which statement BEST describes a main purpose of both passages?

A.Choice: To show readers that video games can teach children

B.Choice: To explain why parents are worried about video games

C.Choice: To tell readers about the kind of video games to play

D.Choice: To teach readers how video games can be both harmful and helpful

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Compare and contrast the most important points and key details presented in two texts on the same topic.
Content: Which important point was made in “Are Video Games Bad for Me?” but NOT in “Why Do Adults Think Video Games Are Bad?”

A.Choice: Video games have ratings.

B.Choice: Families can play video games together.

C.Choice: Video games can be played by more than one person.

D.Choice: Puzzles that ask players to solve problems are good for children.

SubTopics: Write opinion pieces on topics or texts, supporting a point of view with reasons.
Content: After reading the passages, do you think that video games are good for children or bad for children? Write a response in which you clearly state your opinion on the issue. Support your opinion with reasons and details from BOTH passages.
